verb.description: Move in a circular direction wholly or partly around an axis or point.
examples: I turned the key in the door and crept in

verb.description: Move (something) so that it is in a different position in relation to its surroundings or its previous position.
examples: we waited in suspense for him to turn the cards over

verb.description: Change in nature, state, form, or color; become.
Start doing or becoming involved with.
examples: in 1939 he turned to films in earnest
the faceplate is turned rather than cast

noun.description: An act of moving something in a circular direction around an axis or point.
examples: a safety lock requiring four turns of the key

noun.description: A change of direction when moving.
examples: they made a left turn and picked up speed

noun.description: An opportunity or obligation to do something that comes successively to each of a number of people.
examples: it was his turn to speak
why don't you take a turn around the garden?
you gave us quite a turn!

noun.description: The difference between the buying and selling price of stocks or other financial products.
A melodic ornament consisting of the principal note with those above and below it.

phrases: her name seemed to come up at every turn
You start in the catacombs but beware ghostly ghouls at every turn!
It was a mantra repeated at every turn.
Leading a university is no mean job, especially when numerous hurdles await you at every turn.
Kimberly and I remain at Junior Consultant level, banging our heads against the glass ceiling at every turn.
Their idealism turns them against, not towards, the party.
Serena rejects the offer and Lil accuses David of turning Serena against her.
He had robbed Carol and now he was turning Francis against her.
Olympias even managed to turn Alexander against his father.
origin: Old English tyrnan, turnian (verb), from Latin tornare, from tornus lathe, from Greek tornos lathe, circular movement; probably reinforced in Middle English by Old French turner. The noun ( Middle English) is partly from Anglo-Norman French tourn, partly from the verb.
